G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 28.proposition: NOW COMES THE PLAINTIFF, SARAH JOHNSON, and respectfully petitions this Honorable Court to modify the existing custody order entered in this matter on October 15, 2021, pursuant to G.L. c. 208, § 28, G.L. c. 209, § 37, and the equitable authority of the Court.

G.L. c. 209, \u00a7 37.proposition: NOW COMES THE PLAINTIFF, SARAH JOHNSON, and respectfully petitions this Honorable Court to modify the existing custody order entered in this matter on October 15, 2021, pursuant to G.L. c. 208, § 28, G.L. c. 209, § 37, and the equitable authority of the Court.

G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 31.proposition: These circumstances indicate that Michael Smith's behavior and parenting environment may endanger the health, safety, and well-being of Ethan, contrary to the child’s best interest under G.L. c. 208, § 31 and related laws.

Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).proposition: Massachusetts law recognizes that the paramount concern in child custody determinations is the **best interests of the child**. See **Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834 (2003)**; **Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 704 (1985)**.
Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).support_reasoning: The opinion directly discusses the origin and role of the “best interests of the child” standard in Massachusetts custody law and reaffirms that it is the core principle guiding custody determinations. The court explicitly cites Yannas and other cases to state that the best interests of the child is the paramount concern in such matters, thereby clearly supporting the proposition for which it is cited.
Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).relevant_excerpt: “The ‘best interests’ standard appeared in our case law at least as early as 1865… It has been adhered to ever since. See, e.g., Blixt v. Blixt… (best interests standard ‘has long been used in Massachusetts to decide issues of custody and visitation’); Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 704, 710 (1985) (‘best interests of the children always remain the paramount concern’); Surrender of Minor Children, 344 Mass. 230, 234 (1962)… (‘most fundamental [principle] is that the paramount issue is the welfare of the child’).”}

Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 7.proposition: Massachusetts law recognizes that the paramount concern in child custody determinations is the **best interests of the child**. See **Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834 (2003)**; **Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 704 (1985)**.
Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 7.support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly states that in removal and custody matters under Massachusetts law, the child’s best interests are the paramount concern. The court interprets the removal statute’s “upon cause shown” language to mean that removal must be in the best interests of the child and repeatedly frames the analysis around those best interests, thereby supporting the general proposition that Massachusetts custody determinations are governed by the best interests standard.
Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 7.relevant_excerpt: “The Massachusetts removal statute, G. L. c. 208, § 30 (1984 ed.), provides that… ‘upon cause shown’ mean only that removal must be in the best interests of the child (Rubin v. Rubin…; Hale v. Hale, supra at 815), and thus the central question in this case is how these ‘best interests’ are to be determined.… Although the best interests of the children always remain the paramount concern…”

Blixt v. Blixt, 437 Mass. 649 (2002).proposition: Courts have consistently held that evidence of endangerment to a child’s physical or emotional well-being warrants modification of custody orders. See **Blixt v. Blixt, 437 Mass. 649 (2002)**; **Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177 (2006)**.
Blixt v. Blixt, 437 Mass. 649 (2002).support_reasoning: This case concerns the constitutionality and construction of a grandparent visitation statute, not modification of custody orders. While the opinion repeatedly discusses protecting children from harm and the State’s compelling interest in preventing actual or potential harm, it does so in the context of when the State may order grandparent visitation over parental objection, not when custody arrangements may be modified. It therefore does not provide authority for the specific proposition that evidence of endangerment to a child’s physical or emotional well-being warrants modification of custody orders.
Blixt v. Blixt, 437 Mass. 649 (2002).relevant_excerpt: “It cannot be disputed that the State has a compelling interest to protect children from actual or potential harm. … As we shall explain more fully below, the statute can be interpreted to require a showing of harm to the child if visitation is not allowed. So interpreted, the statute furthers a compelling and legitimate State interest in mitigating potential harm to children in nonintact families, an area in which the State has been traditionally and actively involved.”

Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).proposition: Courts have consistently held that evidence of endangerment to a child’s physical or emotional well-being warrants modification of custody orders. See **Blixt v. Blixt, 437 Mass. 649 (2002)**; **Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177 (2006)**.
Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).support_reasoning: Mason v. Coleman is a removal/relocation case applying the ‘best interests of the child’ standard under G.L. c. 208, § 30 in the context of joint physical custody. The court evaluates educational, developmental, relational, and logistical impacts of a proposed move, but it does not articulate a rule that “evidence of endangerment to a child’s physical or emotional well-being warrants modification of custody orders,” nor does it involve a modification of custody based on endangerment. The opinion is about whether to authorize relocation, not about modifying custody because of endangerment; thus, it does not support the specific proposition cited.
Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).relevant_excerpt: “General Laws c. 208, § 30, provides that ‘[a] minor child of divorced parents … shall not … be removed out of this [C]ommonwealth … without the consent of both parents, unless the court upon cause shown otherwise orders.’ ‘The words “upon cause shown” mean only that removal must be in the best interests of the child.’ … We turn to the propriety of the judge’s order denying permission for the mother to remove the children. The order is based on the judge’s findings that the children’s best interests would be negatively affected by this move.”

Schechter v. Schechter, 88 Mass. App. Ct.raw_text: Schechter v. Schechter, 88 Mass. App. Ct. 239 (2015)
Schechter v. Schechter, 88 Mass. App. Ct.proposition: The burden of proof in demonstrating a material change in circumstances and the necessity of modification to protect the child’s best interests lies with the Plaintiff. See **Schechter v. Schechter, 88 Mass. App. Ct. 239 (2015)**.
Schechter v. Schechter, 88 Mass. App. Ct.support_reasoning: The opinion in Schechter is a direct-appeal divorce and 209A case, not a postjudgment modification case. Nowhere does it discuss which party bears the burden of proving a material change in circumstances or the need for modification to protect a child’s best interests. Its discussion of burdens of proof relates to abuse prevention and custody presumptions, not to modification standards, so it does not provide authority for the proposition stated.
Schechter v. Schechter, 88 Mass. App. Ct.relevant_excerpt: “As the statute also expressly provides, ‘a finding by [the Probate and Family Court] by a preponderance of the evidence that a pattern or serious incident of abuse, as defined in [G. L. c. 208, § 31A,] toward a parent or child has occurred shall create a rebuttable presumption that it is not in the best interests of the child to be placed in sole custody, shared legal custody or shared physical custody with the abusive parent’ (emphasis supplied). G. L. c. 209A, § 3(d)…”
